SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Based on the suffix â€œ-ion,â€ the word â€œcompetitionâ€ means

Key.Rationale: This choice is not the meaning of the given suffix added to the base word.
The suffix refers to an action.

This choice is not the meaning of the given suffix added to the base word.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:box:â€œThe shrimp comes with a packet of freeze-dried cocktail sauce that has spicy horseradish in it. 'That gives it a kick,' she says.â€
Which idea does the phrase â€œgives it a kickâ€ suggest?

Key.Rationale: This choice is not the meaning of the figurative language and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This choice is not the meaning of the figurative language and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This choice is not the meaning of the figurative language and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
â€œGives it a kickâ€ suggests that the cocktail sauce has a potent flavor; the word â€œspicyâ€ in the given sentence provides this context.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, steps, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: How are the experiments the students completed related to each other?

A.Choice: They led to the creation of a material that solves a problem.

Key.Rationale: The experiments the students conducted to solve the problem of bone atrophy led them to discover a way to boost flavor in foods for astronauts.

B.Choice: They helped reduce the cost of shipping food to space.

Key.Rationale: Although the use of the students' invention may lead to a reduction in shipping costs for food in space, the product has not been used yet, so the reduction in shipping costs has not yet occurred.

C.Choice: They helped produce a medicine that improves health.

Key.Rationale: The students created a food-flavoring product, not medicine.

D.Choice: They led to a product that will make them money.

Key.Rationale: Although the students may hope to make money from their product, the passage does not indicate that they have profited from their venture yet.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: Which section of the passage has information that is most connected to the diagram at the end of the passage?

Key.Rationale: The information in the section â€œTaste in Spaceâ€ explains how the sense of taste is affected while in space.
The information in the section â€œProblem Solversâ€ explains the original goal of the students â€” to solve the problem of bone atrophy in space.
The information in the section â€œTaste Testâ€ provides details about how the students created the physical structure of the Stellar Strips.
The information in the section explains why the students' invention may be helpful to others.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: How does the diagram of Stellar Strips contribute to the reader's understanding of the passage?

A.Choice: It confirms that Stellar Strips are available in many flavors.

Key.Rationale: The diagram does not give information about the flavors available.

B.Choice: It shows what is used to create the layers of Stellar Strips.

Key.Rationale: The diagram shows what is used to create the layers of the product: two spring-roll wrappers with a layer of flavor extract in the middle.

C.Choice: It illustrates how Stellar Strips are similar to other types of space food.

Key.Rationale: The diagram does not compare Stellar Strips to other types of space food.

D.Choice: It describes the research completed to determine the benefits of Stellar Strips.

Key.Rationale: The diagram does not relay any research.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences and/or making generalizations from the text.
Content: Which evidence from the passage best supports the generalization that Stellar Strips may have benefits on Earth?

A.Choice: â€œ 'It's just like when you have a cold and can't smell the food because you're congested,' says Kloeris.â€

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to the benefits of Stellar Strips on Earth.

B.Choice: â€œOne advantage of Stellar Strips is that they're lightweight.â€

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to the benefits of Stellar Strips on Earth.

C.Choice: â€œLike astronauts, people going through chemotherapy for cancer or taking certain types of medicines experience a decreased sensation of taste.â€

Key.Rationale: The sentence suggests that Stellar Strips may be able to help improve the sense of taste for cancer patients and for people taking other types of medicine.

D.Choice: â€œ 'After all,' says Yoon, 'this is a problem that the world's smartest people are working on.' â€

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to the benefits of Stellar Strips on Earth.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Which statement best expresses main ideas of the passage?

A.Choice: A team of high-school students invented Stellar Strips, and they hope their product will come in many different flavors in the future.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not include information about the effect of space on the sense of taste; in addition, â€œthey hope their product will come in many different flavorsâ€ is a detail, not a main idea.

B.Choice: A group of students wants to develop products that solve global problems, so they are entering contests in hopes of getting approval to expand their ideas.

Key.Rationale: â€œThey are entering contestsâ€ is a detail, not a main idea.

C.Choice: Microgravity in space has caused the bones of astronauts to become weakened, so scientists are researching ways to improve the strength of astronauts.

Key.Rationale: The passage is not mainly about bone atrophy.

D.Choice: Astronauts' sense of taste decreases in space, and the inventors of Stellar Strips hope to solve this problem with their product.

Key.Rationale: The passage explains how space decreases astronauts' sense of taste and tells how a group of students hope to solve this problem by creating flavor strips that enhance the taste of space food.

Content: Which evidence from the passage best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: â€œNow, thanks to a team of high-school students from the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics, tasteless space food could be a thing of the past.â€

Key.Rationale: This choice supports the main ideas that a group of high school students invented Stellar Strips and that this new product may help astronauts to better taste food.

B.Choice: â€œSmell is an important part of taste; if you can't smell food, you can't taste it very well either.â€

Key.Rationale: Athough the sentence relates to the concept of taste, it does not support the ideas of how space affects the sense of taste or how a group of students is attempting to solve this problem.

C.Choice: â€œAstronauts don't have the normal force of gravity pressing on their bones.â€

Key.Rationale: This choice relates to bone atrophy, not to the problem of how space affects the sense of taste.

D.Choice: â€œThe team made a sour-lemon-flavored strip to present to the judges at the Spirit of Innovation Challenge.â€

Key.Rationale: This choice is a detail related to a competition the group of students entered while creating Stellar Strips.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story, drama, or poem, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: In the passage, C.J. Malone has two interactions with Mr. Kelly. Write an essay analyzing how C.J.'s interactions with Mr. Kelly affect her. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.

Content: Which conjunction should fill in the blank to correctly complete the sentence?
:box:Mom said that _________ my sister nor I had homework, so we could do something fun.

Key.Rationale: This conjunction does not fit within the context of the sentence.
â€œNeitherâ€ fits within the context of the sentence.
